estimated_calories.notes: Calories are estimated based on a standard serving size of mixed cruciferous vegetables (broccoli, asparagus) without added fats or sauces. Actual calories may vary if oils, cheeses, or dressings are included.

macronutrient_breakdown.notes: Macronutrients are primarily from fiber-rich vegetables. Fat content assumes no added oils or butter.

key_vitamins_and_minerals.vitamin_C: High (broccoli and asparagus are excellent sources)
key_vitamins_and_minerals.vitamin_K: High (cruciferous vegetables like broccoli are rich in K)
key_vitamins_and_minerals.notes: Cruciferous vegetables are nutrient-dense and provide a wide array of micronutrients.

health_benefits.anti-inflammatory: Broccoli and asparagus contain antioxidants like sulforaphane and flavonoids.
health_benefits.digestive_health: High fiber content supports gut health and regularity.
health_benefits.bone_health: Vitamin K aids in calcium absorption and bone metabolism.
health_benefits.detoxification: Cruciferous vegetables support liver detox pathways.

dietary_concerns.fodmaps: Broccoli and asparagus contain FODMAPs (may irritate IBS sufferers in large quantities).
dietary_concerns.thyroid_interaction: Cruciferous vegetables in very large amounts may affect thyroid function in sensitive individuals (rare).

recommendations_for_a_healthier_meal.add_protein: Include lean protein (e.g., grilled chicken, tofu, or lentils) to make it more balanced.
recommendations_for_a_healthier_meal.healthy_fats: Add avocado or drizzle with olive oil for satiety and fat-soluble vitamin absorption.
recommendations_for_a_healthier_meal.portion_control: Ensure vegetables fill at least half the plate for volume and nutrients.
recommendations_for_a_healthier_meal.seasoning_tips: Use herbs, lemon juice, or garlic instead of heavy sauces or salt.
recommendations_for_a_healthier_meal.cooking_methods: Steam or roast instead of frying to preserve nutrients.
